{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2961955,"name":"Ryan C.","username":"RC625","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/c68b51/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-07-15T23:07:25.746Z","cooked":"

Hi all,
In doing wire extensions for power wires, is it optimal to use soldering or power pole to connect the original wire and extending wire together?

I am guessing that power pole connectors take more time to make, needing to crimp and assemble connectors, but can be easily disconnected. Although, these power wires can be disconnected through the power pole connectors stemming from the component connected, or be disconnected from the PDP port.

What are your suggestions on this? Thanks in advance.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2021-07-15T23:30:53.415Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":280,"reads":404,"readers_count":403,"score":1485.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":395089,"topic_slug":"wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors","display_username":"Ryan C.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41732,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1351 Battery specialist, Electronics Lead"},"post_url":"/t/wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors/395089/1","custom_user_title":"1351 Battery specialist, Electronics Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2961957,"name":"Lucus Zha","username":"lucuszha","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lucuszha/{size}/134441_2.png","created_at":"2021-07-15T23:18:25.333Z","cooked":"

We always use powerpole connectors. Before build season, we make sure that everyone has a LOT of training with both crimping and attaching casings, up to the point where any reasonably experienced member can crimp and assemble a wire in under 20 seconds, which is a lot faster than we could reasonably power up our soldering iron and make extensions for any set of wires.

in my experience, the main advantage of soldering power wires is that they don‚Äôt come apart very often, but if your powerpole connectors have a habit of coming apart (they usually don‚Äôt), you can fasten them with either small zip-ties or custom plates.

Hope this helps y‚Äôall!

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2021-07-15T23:18:25.333Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":398,"readers_count":397,"score":89.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":395089,"topic_slug":"wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors","display_username":"Lucus Zha","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37377,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":" 948 Electrical/Design"},"post_url":"/t/wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors/395089/3","custom_user_title":" 948 Electrical/Design","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2961958,"name":"Rishi Rao","username":"22raor","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/22raor/{size}/127971_2.png","created_at":"2021-07-15T23:22:29.151Z","cooked":"

We use these PowerPole retention clips to keep them from coming apart.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2021-07-15T23:22:29.151Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":384,"readers_count":383,"score":241.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":395089,"topic_slug":"wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors","display_username":"Rishi Rao","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":37377,"username":"lucuszha","name":"Lucus Zha","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lucuszha/{size}/134441_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":10}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41300,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"8429 Mentor | 4926 Alum"},"post_url":"/t/wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors/395089/4","custom_user_title":"8429 Mentor | 4926 Alum","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":10}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":10,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2961959,"name":"Ryan C.","username":"RC625","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/c68b51/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-07-15T23:37:55.843Z","cooked":"

We use these too. I think I may use them for mechanisms.

In the event of a mechanism motors having their throttles stuck open/ moving too far so that it pulls on the wires, Is having the power pole with the clip pulled apart better than relying the the soldering wire strength to hold the connection?

Have mechanisms managed to pull apart soldered connections in wires before?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2021-07-15T23:38:29.387Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":372,"readers_count":371,"score":94.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":395089,"topic_slug":"wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors","display_username":"Ryan C.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":41300,"username":"22raor","name":"Rishi Rao","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/22raor/{size}/127971_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41732,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1351 Battery specialist, Electronics Lead"},"post_url":"/t/wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors/395089/5","custom_user_title":"1351 Battery specialist, Electronics Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2961960,"name":"Rishi Rao","username":"22raor","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/22raor/{size}/127971_2.png","created_at":"2021-07-15T23:43:11.470Z","cooked":"

Well, replacing the clip is a lot quicker than soldering again, which is especially useful at a competition.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2021-07-15T23:43:11.470Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":364,"readers_count":363,"score":97.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":395089,"topic_slug":"wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors","display_username":"Rishi Rao","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":41732,"username":"RC625","name":"Ryan C.","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/c68b51/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41300,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"8429 Mentor | 4926 Alum"},"post_url":"/t/wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors/395089/6","custom_user_title":"8429 Mentor | 4926 Alum","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2961961,"name":"bobbysq","username":"bobbysq","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bobbysq/{size}/195893_2.png","created_at":"2021-07-15T23:47:14.735Z","cooked":"
RC625:

In the event of a mechanism motors having their throttles stuck open/ moving too far so that it pulls on the wires, Is having the power pole with the clip pulled apart better than relying the the soldering wire strength to hold the connection?

Ideally, you have a hard stop so the mechanism physically can‚Äôt do that. If it does, you‚Äôre probably better off having the wires disconnect at the connectors than having them break in a less predictable (and more dangerous) place along the wire.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2021-07-15T23:47:14.735Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":362,"readers_count":361,"score":162.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":395089,"topic_slug":"wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors","display_username":"bobbysq","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28014,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"he/him"},"post_url":"/t/wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors/395089/7","custom_user_title":"he/him","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2961986,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2021-07-16T15:55:14.927Z","cooked":"

Solder. Better connection, both physically and for the current path. Cleaner, lighter, cheaper per connection.

Of course there is some level of competency involved for both power poles and soldering.

Just my $0.02

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2021-07-16T15:55:14.927Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":335,"readers_count":334,"score":92.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":395089,"topic_slug":"wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors/395089/8","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2961988,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2021-07-16T16:38:53.804Z","cooked":"

Power poles are my go-to connector for 10 - 16 AWG wires. For a splice, I‚Äôd recommend a crimped butt splice, similar to these.

amazon.com

amazon.com

Proper crimps are both stronger and have less electrical resistance than solder. Don‚Äôt use the cheap crimping tool made from metal plate like the ones that come in the cheap crimp kits; get a ratcheting crimper or a least some real 9+" crimping pliers similar to this:

https://www.homedepot.com/p/Channellock-9-1-2-in-Crimping-Pliers-909/202304949

As with power poles, be sure to strip the right amount of wire - the wire should ‚Äúbottom out‚Äù in the connector just as the insulation hits the metal of the connector, giving you the best in connectivity where you want it, insulation where you want that, and durability when flexed.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2021-07-16T17:04:48.290Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":334,"readers_count":333,"score":166.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":395089,"topic_slug":"wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors","display_username":"Gus Michel II","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.amazon.com/dp/B06XCNQCHQ","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":32},{"url":"https://www.homedepot.com/p/Channellock-9-1-2-in-Crimping-Pliers-909/202304949","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":25},{"url":"https://www.amazon.com/dp/B06XCX7WRV","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":16}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22335,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú "},"post_url":"/t/wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors/395089/9","custom_user_title":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2961996,"name":"JamesCH95","username":"JamesCH95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jamesch95/{size}/1200_2.png","created_at":"2021-07-16T17:29:04.855Z","cooked":"

For wire extension that need servicing it is hard to beat a power-pole. For wire extensions that can be essentially permanent I‚Äôd suggest a crimped butt splice with clear adhesive heat shrink so that the junction can be inspected after assembly.

RC625:

I am guessing that power pole connectors take more time to make, needing to crimp and assemble connectors

I would posit exactly the opposite, when the proper tools are used. Not needing to wait for anything to heat up, or cool down, makes crimping faster than soldering. Here is a video of crimping ferrules, but the same general process applies to power-pole connectors.

Here is link to the NASA workmanship standard related to soldering vs crimping.

Crimping is an efficient and highly reliable method to assemble and terminate conductors, and typically provides a stronger, more reliable termination method than that achieved by soldering.

Here is a test-section I did this week for an EV client of mine. This is a 2/0 gauge copper wire crimped with a $70 hydraulic crimper to a copper lug. The connection is solid copper that has been cold-welded together. It does not really get lower-resistance or stronger than that.

image1119√ó840 120 KB

tl;dr - If you use the right tools and terminals to crimp it will outperform soldering by nearly any performance metric.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2021-07-16T17:30:33.002Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":314,"readers_count":313,"score":277.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":395089,"topic_slug":"wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors","display_username":"JamesCH95","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://workmanship.nasa.gov/lib/insp/2%20books/links/sections/201%20General%20Requirements.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"CRIMPED TERMINATIONS GENERAL REQUIREMENTS","clicks":8},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/e/0/e0414b82e67b304edb558ecada26a1e6e33dd128.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bUQRLeDp7UI","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":11}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3782,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors/395089/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":11}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":11,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2962005,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2021-07-16T19:28:41.817Z","cooked":"

That is a spectacular crimp - just like downtown - the way it should be. As @JamesCH95 pointed out, most of those outstanding results are from the knowledge about how to do it right and not a million dollar tool.

Contrast that with solder (which I‚Äôm not recommending):

  • Huge amounts of heat being applied to the connector
  • Many seconds of heating
  • Heat going from the connector down into the wire (which in that example has substantial mass with very good heat conductivity)
  • Damage to the insulation
  • With all that mass getting up to soldering temperature, it‚Äôll take a long time to cool down so you‚Äôll need to keep everything very still for the substantial part of a minute as the solder cools to even have a chance at as decent connection

And those aren‚Äôt even the deal killers IMO. The deal killer is:

  • Solder has wicked into the wire - probably for a substantial distance - which will cause the wire to become rigid (basically solid) where the solder wicked in which means all future stresses will be concentrated exactly at that point (where the solder wicking stopped). It‚Äôs just about as close to a guaranteed failure point as you can get - yikes!

Solder is great for circuit boards - for extending wires, crimp connectors are going to outperform it AND be way easier to do (I can solder pretty well and have been doing it for over 40 years - I would cringe at having to solder the example in @JamesCH95 post and would try as hard as I could to talk someone out of it doing it and actually do it only under protest).

A good crimp is mechanically solid, electrically low resistance, and long lasting because the connector to conductor interface is so solid it is gas-tight.

You just need the right tools with a little practice and you‚Äôll be a crimp-master too.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":31,"updated_at":"2021-07-16T19:30:59.641Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":291,"readers_count":290,"score":153.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":395089,"topic_slug":"wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors","display_username":"Chris Herzog","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":3782,"username":"JamesCH95","name":"JamesCH95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jamesch95/{size}/1200_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":40142,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]"},"post_url":"/t/wire-extensions-soldering-or-power-pole-connectors/395089/11","custom_user_title":"Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2962006,"name":"Richard Wallace","username":"Richard_Wallace","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/richard_wallace/{size}/110760_2.png","created_at":"2021-07-16T19:42:19.121Z","cooked":"

I‚Äôm in the crimp-it camp, because of time spent* analyzing the evil results of wiring failures caused by the exact mechanism that Chris describes:

zog:

The deal killer is:

  • Solder has wicked into the wire - probably for a substantial distance - which will cause the wire to become rigid (basically solid) where the solder wicked in which means all future stresses will be concentrated exactly at that point (where the solder wicking stopped). It‚Äôs just about as close to a guaranteed failure point as you can get - yikes!

*No, I will not link stories; they are the stuff of lawsuits and non-disclosure agreements. Property damaged, and sometimes lives lost. Solder joints are not used in North American residential appliances, except on printed wiring boards. That prohibition exists in other product areas also.

OP: Just so you know, you will get 100 different answers to this, each one claiming to be right or some sort of standard of some organization.

Test, find what your team likes and is most convenient and go from there. Both options are run by many teams with both success and failure.

A lot of times I agree with the sentiment but here the spectrum isn‚Äôt as smooth as it might seem.

A decent crimp will just about be 100% on the success side while even a good solder connection (which might work now) will be heading towards the failure end of the spectrum and probably picking up speed before too long.

There really is a right / best way to do this and it‚Äôs pretty easy to do.

There are modern versions of these that can make the joint with a heat gun (or even a match allegedly) using a low temp solder and even a surrounding piece of heat shrink tubing (which gives you an idea of the amount of heat involved when you think about shrinking tubing).

amazon.com

The vendor claims them as ‚Äúwaterproof‚Äù - I‚Äôd consider them as ‚Äúprobably able to survive a very infrequent modest splash of a small amount of water-proof‚Äù.

I‚Äôve got some that I‚Äôve messed with - they seem to ‚Äúworkish‚Äù but I don‚Äôt trust them for anything non-trivial.

I consider them more zombie apocalypse / end of the world trick bag stuff at this point - if I‚Äôve got access to the right things, I‚Äôll use that.

Though I‚Äôve seen the ones you referenced and they are cool and I know you‚Äôre not suggesting using them on a robot. They have a certain appeal‚Ä¶

zog:

There really is a right / best way to do this and it‚Äôs pretty easy to do.

Exactly this. I‚Äôve read up on the subject extensively and talked to people who have designed wire crimping equipment. When NASA, the automotive industry, and every power utility agree‚Ä¶ Well‚Ä¶ That‚Äôs an awfully compelling situation.

Now, I don‚Äôt want anyone to get me wrong on this. I have a soldering iron. I have soldering splices. Sometimes soldering is the right call, and sometimes soldering is the only call (like getting a racecar back on track and you simply don‚Äôt have the right terminal). But when you‚Äôre in your shop and you have a minute or a day to do it right, crimp it.

zog:

I consider them more zombie apocalypse / end of the world trick bag stuff at this point - if I‚Äôve got access to the right things, I‚Äôll use that.

Well, that‚Äôs sort of the purpose (explained in the video). Out in a war zone, have to make a quick connection. Carrying extra tools is extra weight in the pack. Needs to be fool-proof.

Cool tech. Good to be aware that it exists.

efoote868:

Well, that‚Äôs sort of the purpose (explained in the video). Out in a war zone, have to make a quick connection. Carrying extra tools is extra weight in the pack. Needs to be fool-proof.

You know just in case.

In regards to being fool-proof; is it just me or does it seem like the evolutionary development of fools seem like it‚Äôs picking up speed?
